msDesc.head: Medical treatises and recipes

msItem.title: Notes for two medical recipes
msItem.note: The notes include medicines for ffleme and stoma (? stomach). Added in the late 15th or early 16th century. Not recorded in Mooney (1995).

msItem.title: Uroscopic token list
msItem.incipit: i recto Vryn lyk whey and thyn with a cercull purpull do the verr lyk blod in the bothem synyfiet straytnes in the brest a tyssyk gret coldnes and gret hete of handes and feet gret dyssdard in the bak and none apetyt to ete but [...] Per Magister S. Heryson probatum est
msItem.note: Full transcription largely following Mooney (1995), p. 53. Added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: Tract on the Perilous Days
msItem.incipit: i recto Saynt beed tellethe þe perlowes daies That is the last day of aprill the fyrst day [sic] awgust and þe last day [sic] decanber yf he let blod any of thes dayes or ete any gose flesshe or takythe any sekenes schall dye within xiiijne dayes after also beware in any wise of þe fyrst monday of august the last monday of þe same moneth and the last monday of descember also there be iij dayes in þe yer and iij nyghtes in the whiche yf a chylt be beried in any 3 then his body shall neuer rote in erthe that is the last monday of january the fyrst and last monday of ffebruare
msItem.note: Full transcription largely following Mooney (1995), p. 53. Added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: Four medical recipes
msItem.note: The second recipe is for improving appetite and attributed to L. Darcy. Added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: On the longevity of nine creatures
msItem.incipit: i verso Here tellith howe long ix maner of thynges shuld leue as clarkes sayeth Item a hegge dureth iij yeres Item j dogge durith iij heges summa ix yeres A horse iij dogges summa xxvij yeres A man iij horses summa lxxx yeres A hart durethe iij men summa ij centum xliiij yerys A raven iij hertes summa vij centum xxix yeres An egell dureth iij ravens summa ij decem centum lxxxvij yeris A whale durith iij egelles þat is vj mille v centum lxvj yeres
msItem.note: Full transcription largely following Mooney (1995), p. 53. Added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: Note on the the Age of the World attributed to Roger Bacon
msItem.incipit: i verso Some of the wherld ye\a/res as I have reade in old writteres of Roger Bakones ys 19783
msItem.note: Full transcription as in Mooney (1995), p. 53. Added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Table of contents for the volume
msItem.rubric: 1:1r The contentis withynne this volume bien thiese as in this table and kalender folowyng plainly is expressed
msItem.incipit: 1:1r The treatice of taryng and withdrawyng thaccidentis of age after ffriere Rogier Bacon of thorder of Menours
msItem.explicit: 1:5v Of medicynes dyuersly treatid bi John Mary Janewey Doctour Sutton and bi Maister Rogier Necton doctours in phisik
msItem.note: A later hand has added Friar Roger Bacon to the top of f. 1r. Other 15th-century hands have added marginal notes.

msItem.title: On Tarrying the Accidents of Old Age (English translation of De retardatione accidentium senectutis)
msItem.author: Pseudo-Roger Bacon
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with Latin chapter headings
msItem.rubric: 2:1r The treatice of ffreere Rogier Bacon of thorder of Menours of tarieng and withdrawyng the accidentis of age and of aldermen
msItem.incipit: 2:1r Lord of the world of whiche of the most noblest stokk hast take the spryng and the bigynnyng higheste god to whos goodenes and holynes al thynges wonne and opteyned doeth com by I thynk and have thought of many werkis evene pleasaunt to thy highnes I have stied on high and I have founde an hard thung but often fallible to shewe or deme I have serchid thentraile and bowels of therth: and ther have I founde the vanite and losse of tyme: ffortvne hath brought me in a meane for the litilnes of my soule and in hym I have founde .iij. doctrynes necessarie wrappid to a prynce long tyme to lordship and to reigne
msItem.explicit: 2:28r Thyng whiche lieth in the bowels of therth is preparat in the x degre repaired and þing whiche swymmyth in the see and whiche growith in the aire and thyng whiche goeth out myners of noble beestes temperate and equal of complexioun in al the body
msItem.finalRubric: 2:28r Here endithe the treatice of ffrere Rogier Bacon of the Rule of Helthe and Accidentis of Age
msItem.note: As Mooney (1995) notes, the upper margin of f. 2:1r features the monogram of John de Vale, secretary to Sir Thomas Cook, Mayor of London, 1462-1463. The work consists of a prologue, followed by sixteen chapters.

msItem.title: De spermate (English translation)
msItem.author: Pseudo-Galen
msItem.incipit: 2:28r Sperme of man descendith of al the humours of the body that it be made more subtile in nature of the .iiij. humours of mannes body fforsoth this pserme hath nerues and veynes propirly even drawyng from al the body to the testicules or ballokkes that nervis and veynes of frotyng and chaufyng of man and womman putten out as with smytyng of iron and stone fuyre whiche nervis and veynes bien dyuersed from the nervis and veynes of the vryne
msItem.explicit: 2:37r It happith forsoth that sum man is sapient and poore and sum a foole and riche sum faire born of foule fader and moder and in the contrary forwhi many thynges we bien to say but we mown nat seyn hem now as of the subtilite
msItem.note: The title Sperme of man has been added by a later hand in the outer margin of f. 2:28r.
In the outer margin of f. 2:28r is written the following note: Þe sperme of man. hotter etcaetera Note J D .1573..

listBibl.bibl: Pahta and Carrillo Linares (2006), I: pp. 95-117

msItem.title: De XII portis (De XII signis) [English translation]
msItem.incipit: 2:36v It is to be wist that of .xij. signes .iij. bien hoote and drie
msItem.explicit: 2:40v It bihovith that the leche knowe the tyme of the infirmyte day and hour what planete it was and in what signe whan the sike bigan to sikel if the infirmyte be after the propirte of the signe

msItem.title: De natura humana (English translation)
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with a Latin title
msItem.rubric: 2:40v Liber Cerebri
msItem.incipit: 2:40v The brayn naturaly is cold and moist to suscepcioun or takyng and therfor as of dyuers lightly it turnyth and as to moevyng membris leuyth and yevith the mobilite and as to calefaccion and drie spirite to the hede of temperat breth bryngith in of whos myng is cold drie and thikke withyn whom forsoth bien divisions or departynges
msItem.explicit: 2:44r But this lettith nature and frowardly parformyth fforwhy whan any happe lettith or foryetith that matier superflue moist whiche to wast or to nombre of any other membre wont to dispose nature moche without reasooun in so moche

listBibl.bibl: Pahta and Carrillo Linares (2006), I: pp. 95-117

msItem.title: Instructions for protecting cloth or wood from fire
msItem.incipit: 2:44r If thow wilt that tree or cloth brenne nat take argent vif or quik siluer and put it in aisel til it be matured ripe and touche cloth or tree and after that from fuyre it lepith
msItem.note: The title Not burne has been added by a later hand to the outer margin of f. 2:44r.
Full transcription as in Mooney (1995), p. 54.

msItem.title: Treatise on phlebotomy
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with Latin title
msItem.rubric: 2:44v Liber fleobotomie
msItem.incipit: 2:44v Ueray fleobotomye or letyng of bloode is right inscicioun or cuttyng of veynes with reasoun of mynusioun and lassyng of bloode moderatly and manerly in effusioun of whiche places wee fleobotomye the bodie of mankynde of veynes and arterijs .ij. bien cut behynd the earis .ij. agenst the eyen .ij. in the forhede .iiij. in the hynder part of the hede
msItem.explicit: 2:46r ffleobotomye the mynde clensith . Memory yevith . the blader purgith . the brayne evene temperith . the mary chauffith . the heryng openyth . teeris stroyneth . the stomac purgith . digestioun helpith . lighter voice . bryngith . the wit sharpith . the wombe coartith . Sleepe mynusith . dulnes . sorowe . and hevynes awey takith . lust and likyng coartith propre bloode norisshith . and straunge outcastith length of lif and hele mynistreth
msItem.note: The title Blode lattyng has been added by a later hand to the outer margin of f. 2:44v.

msItem.title: Medical recipes for treating skin disorders
msItem.incipit: 2:46r To the variole whiche is made of bloode if ti be in yowth to be fleobotomyed vnto spetemy and it is to yeve hem cold and moiste diete pustules forsoth bien to be enoynted with oynement made of braunchis of the vyne and turion that is of aglienter the tendrouns of both forsoth ought to be brent the asshen of either to be tempered with oile forsoth with that oignement tho pustules oughten to be enoynted
msItem.explicit: 2:46v and in the drie shadewe and whan it needith dissolue it in water and cast it in the nosethirls and hold open the mowth that the humour may renne out
msItem.note: The title Oyntmentes ffor highe coloure pustules has been added by a later hand to the outer margin of f. 2:46r.

msItem.title: De coitu (incomplete English translation)
msItem.author: Constantinus Africanus
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with Latin title
msItem.rubric: 2:46v Incipit liber creatoris
msItem.incipit: 2:46v The creator and maker of al thyng willyng that kynd stidefastly and stably abide bi that drift and bi generacioun hath disposed to revoke as revoked of al no losse to be had therfore whan he fulfillith beestis with natural membris whiche to this werk bien apt and propir to them only to that wondirful vertu and to friendly and amyable delectacioun hath sowen as that no beeste be whiche nat bi lasse delitith in drift
msItem.explicit: 2:50r now thiese thynges fulfill turne we to tho thynges whiche provoken drivyng whiche sum bie nas we say whiche forsoth mown nat appetite and expowne we what departith hem from appetite
msItem.finalRubric: 2:50r Now thiese thynges fulfille turne we to tho thynges whiche provoken drivyng whiche sum bien as we say whiche forsoth mown nat appetite and expowne we what departith hem from appetite
msItem.note: The title Liber Creatoris has been added by a later hand to the outer margin of f. 2:46v. The treatise appears to have been left unfinished.

msItem.title: Collection of 13 medical recipes
msItem.note: The last recipe is for Broek nbone in a mans hed.

The recipes have been added by a late 15th- or early 16th-century hand. One recipe for stoppyng of flowres on f. 2:52v is attributed to M[agister] Lewis, perhaps Kery Lewes [Lewis] (fl. c. 1472-1510), who was a student of medicine at Cambridge and fellow of King's Hall (1472-3). C.H. Talbot and E.A. Hammond The Medical Practitioners in Medieval England: A Biographical Register (London: WEllcome Historical Medicine LIbrary, 1965), p. 204 suggest that he is the "Master Lewes" who was physician to Mary, Princess of Castille; and 'Master Lewes the Queen's physician' who occurs in accounts of Henry VII. He also received a monetary reward from King Henry VIII in 1510. Other recipes attributed to a Magister Lowes, doctor in medicines occur in London, British Library, Harley MS 1628. In Trinity College MS R.14.52, one other recipe occurs that has been attributed to him on f. 2:138v.

msItem.title: Tract on the virtues of Artemisia (excerpt of the Viridibus Herbarum)
msItem.author: Macer Floridus
msItem.rubric: 2:51v The vertue of Arthimesia
msItem.incipit: 2:51v Id est matere herbarum modour worte and the modere of yerbes gave her þe name dyana in grewe and oon arthemesius ffownd ffyrst the vertu of this hot and drye in 3 degre and the leues be bettere then the roote hit helpeth woman to conceue child hit purgethe modere and cawse wemen to haue there fflowres
msItem.explicit: 2:52r and ley it to a boche and drynke the iuse of the said yerbe with wyn and be hole also yf ye dryng þe iuce of this yerbe ofte þer shall now weked best greue the
msItem.note: The title fflowres has been added by the same hand that added the tract to the outer margin of f. 2:51v.

msItem.title: Heading for a treatise on the planets
msItem.rubric: 2:52r Tretes of þe exposcyen of þe vij celestiall bodyes or planetes and of þer affectes and influence as fyrst of saturne iupiter and marse 239
msItem.note: According to Mooney (1995), this is a "[h]eading for a treatise on the planets, for which no text follows". However, Mooney transcribes the number that concludes the number as 23us, not realising that it is a reference to f. 2:239r where a treatise on the seven planets and their influence on mankind indeed begins.

msItem.title: Tract or sermon on man's recognisation of the Godhead
msItem.author: William Haekins [Hawkins], Vicar of Bridge Sollers, Herefordshire
msItem.rubric: 2:52r Bacon is burthened to fayne of mani godes but there is but one true god which do leue euer and allwayes
msItem.incipit: 2:52r We hovlde yt out of controversie þat there ys in the minde of man euen bi naturall instinction a certayned felinge of godhed for to the ende þat no man shovld flee to the presence of ignoravnce god himsheelf hath plantid in all men a certeine vnderstanding of his devine magiste
msItem.explicit: 2:52v they do inded loke abovt for all þe startnge holles þat may be to hide themselves in from þe prisence of þe lord finis bi me william haekins vicar of brvdge solars
msItem.note: A sermon on natural monotheism added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Extract on the Prologation of Life from In debito regimine
msItem.author: Roger Bacon
msItem.incipit: 2:53r Frere Rogier Bacon in the .vj. booke of sentences in the .iij. degre of sapience wher he spekith of goodis of the body and of goodis of fortune and of goodis of honest maners as he seiþ in diew rule of body and prolongyng of lif to the vttermest termes natural whiche god hath ordeigned and nature ageyn lightneth bi power of Astronomye . Alkamye . and perspectief and of sciences experimental
msItem.explicit: 2:56v and therfor if the first mirrour so be of sufficient quantite and of diew figuracioun it may bryng infynite fuyre and in to euery distaunce and ferof as we wiln fforsoth bi this maner myrrour mown bien gadred the beames of al vertuous sterris as bien made high operaciouns and most profitable in this world etcaetera
msItem.note: A marginal note identifies this text as acon libro vjo sententiarum in iijo gradu sapiencie in the outer margin of f. 2:53r.

msItem.title: Extract on the Prologation of Life from Corpora Adae et Evae
msItem.author: Roger Bacon
msItem.rubric: 2:56v Also another treatise of the same ffrere Rogier Bacon drawen oute of the .vj. partie of compendious studie of Theologie from word to word whiche booke he made at the instaunce of pope Clement and is the treatice of matiers bifore drawen and is drawen of the chapitre that he entitled of sciences experimental And whosumeuer wil have more fully doctryne and aunswer to the difficultees the whiche mown be obiect in the contrarie secke he the principal scriptures that is to say the booke of the .vj. sciences and the booke that he hath entitled of compendious studie of Theologie and he shal fynde ther matier with difficultees diffusely treated
msItem.incipit: 2:56v-2:57r Forsoth the bodies of adam and of Eve after their synne thei withdriew moche further of from equalite than thei wern in the state of innocence but only as to the respect of our bodies in thiese daies thei driew moche more to equalite than we do now and therfor thei myghten long live
msItem.explicit: 2:61r Which bien veray triewe remedies and what thynges thei take it as founde most in the booke of secretis of Aristotil and in the philosophie of Archepius and in the booke of passiouns of age and in the treatice of age and rule of eldermen and in the bookis of plinius and elliswher in many maners
msItem.finalRubric: 2:61r Explicit tractatus extractus de predicto libro ffratris Roegri Bacon

msItem.title: Extract from the Regimen sanitatis Salernitanum
msItem.incipit: 2:61r Ista calor vigent .3.a salsus amarus acutus alget acetosus
msItem.explicit: 2:61r Stipticus insipidus . cum falso sunt mediocres

msItem.title: List of contagious diseases
msItem.incipit: 2:61r ffebres acuta . pstisis pedicon sacer ignis / Et scabies lepra . sunt morbi contagiosi

msItem.title: Medical recipe for the flux
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with a Latin title

msItem.title: Commentary on the Hippocratic Prognostics, Book 1
msItem.rubric: 2:62r Vpon pronosticacions
msItem.incipit: 2:62r It is to be noted after bartilmew vpon pronosticaciouns that of signes other bien rememoratief or remembrid of tyme past that is to say as of causis demonstratief shewed in tyme present as of infirmytes pronostical in tyme to come as of tho infirmytees to be determyned owther to life or deth
msItem.explicit: 2:81v Bi this that it is nat of evil odoure signifieth that nature is strong in depuryng who forsoth hath the contrary condiciouns that is to say as that it be of horrible odour or of strong stynche signifieth putrefaccioun and no maturacioun as saith galien in his coment and so of the other accidentis ther is contrarie
msItem.note: The title Pronosticaciones has been added by a later hand to the outer margin of f. 2:62r.

msItem.title: Commentary on the Hippocratic Prognostics, Book 2
msItem.incipit: 2:82r Al dropesie in sharp sikenes is evil and hastith forsoth þe fever and hevynes of membris and ache
msItem.explicit: 2:104r and without labour thiese therfor bien evil for whither signifien grete matier [...]
msItem.note: Medical treatise of 45 chapters covering a wide range of subjects, including dropsy, sleep, diagnosis by urine, vomit, and spittal, citing Avicen, Bartholomeus, Galienus, Iprocras.

Mooney (1995) suggests that the treatise may be corrupt and incomplete as indicated by the scribe's errors and their decision to leave the rest of f. 104r and the two subsequent leaves (ff. 105-106) blank. The final line is illegible.

msItem.title: Collection of 36 recipes
msItem.note: The recipes are all medical except for the first one, which provides instructions for making a sered clothe, and the final one, which provides instructions þo take byrdes.
Added by a late 15th- or early 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Prognostications by thunder (brontomantia) in each of the months
msItem.rubric: 2:105r Off thuderyng þat fallythe in dyuerse monethes of yere and what they synyfyethe
msItem.incipit: 2:105r Janyuer thonderyng betokenythe gret wynd and batelles corne and ffurt shal be plente and dethe of men
msItem.explicit: 2:105v Descember synyfiethe plente of corne pece and loue in erthe
msItem.note: The title Thonderynges has been added to the outer margin on f. 2:105r.
Added by a late 15th- or early 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: On the Three Perilous Mondays
msItem.incipit: 2:105v Also there ys iij perelous mondayes in the [sic] yf a child be gotten or borne in any of the iij mondayes they shall dy a shamus dethe and yf a man yet any gose ffleshe on any of thos iij mondays vij yere after he shal be spilt of gret seknes and hit yll to begyn any good werk that is to wet the ffyrst monday of ffebruare the last monday of may ant the last monday of september
msItem.note: The title iij perelous mondayes has been added to the margin of f. 205v.
Added by a late 15th- or early 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: The Sekenesse of Wymmen [Second redaction of a Middle English translation of the gynecological and obstetrical chapters of the Compendium medicine]
msItem.author: Gilbertus Anglicus
msItem.incipit: 2:107r For as moche as ther bien many wymmen that han many diuers maladies and sikenessis nygh to the deth and they also bien shameful to shewen and to tellen their grevaunces to any wight therfor I shal sumdel write to their maladie remedy prayeng to god to sende me grace triewly to write to the plesaunce of god
msItem.explicit: 2:134v Another medicyne for wymmen that may nat conceive take the stones and the liver ofa pigge that is delivered of sow alon and make powder therof and gyve the womman to drynke with wyne whan she goeth to bedde to hir make and she shal conceive witnesse trotula
msItem.note: Two later hands have added marginal notes.

msItem.title: Collection of six medical recipes
Collection of 24 medical recipes
msItem.note: Added in the late 15th or early 16th century. On f. 2:136v are two recipes that are said to have been proved or made by Buknam. On f. 2:138v is a recipe for treating sores that is attributed to M[agister] Lewes [perhaps the Cambridge-trained physician Kery Lewes, see the note accompanying ff. 2:50r-2:51v].

msItem.title: Recipes for medicinal syrups
msItem.rubric: 2:137v Here ffoluythe xij syrupes þat bythe comyn syrupes at the pottycares
msItem.incipit: 2:137v The ffyrst syrupe is called Oxynell whiche ys in iij maner The ffyrst is sympell The ijde ys compownde The iijde is de compownud
msItem.explicit: 2:138r the sympell ys good for all maner fflyx of late comyng the compound is good for all old flixe as in the stomak in the bowelles and sich othere
msItem.note: Added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: On the use of seven distilled waters
msItem.rubric: 2:138v Waters Stylled
msItem.incipit: 2:138v Aqua wormod ys good for þe lyuer ffellen stomak wormes in þe wombe ffor þe jawndice dronkenness for þe sighte and ffor the marras
msItem.explicit: 2:138v Aqua nept yf hit be dronken ofte hit makethe womman lusty and yonge
msItem.note: Added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: Tract on the Four Elements and Four Complexions of Mankind
msItem.rubric: 2:139r The .iiij. Elementis
msItem.incipit: 2:139r It is to vndirstonde that ther bien iiij elementis ffuyr eire water and erth whos qualites and prevy worchynges bien þese the fuyre is hote and drie the aire hoote and moiste the water cold and moiste and the erth cold and drie
msItem.explicit: 2:139v vryne white thynne and cliere bitokenyth that malencoly haþ dominacioun
msItem.finalRubric: 2:139v Here endith the iiij elementis and their qualitees

msItem.title: Notes on elements, suffixed to the previous text on the Four Elements
msItem.incipit: 2:139v An element is a simple boy vnder the domynacioun of the mone whos partes in kynde varien not. A commyxtioun of Elementis is colde a knyttyng toguyder in bodies
msItem.note: Full transcription as in Mooney (1995), p. 58.

msItem.title: Tract on the Three Spirits of Mankind (Natural, Vital, and Animal)
msItem.incipit: 2:139v Ther bien in every man .iij. spirites . ffirst the natural spirit the secunde the vital spirit the thridde the animal spirit
msItem.explicit: 2:140r But his chief abidyng is in the middil celle that is calde the celle of reason

msItem.title: Tract on the three stages of digestion in stomach, liver, and heart
msItem.incipit: 2:140r Al the mete and drynk that man receivith haþ .iij. digestions The first in the stomac . the secunde in the liver wher ther is a subtil evaporatioun made and sent bit the veynes and turnyth in to bloode that goeth to the herte
msItem.explicit: 2:140r And so it is open inowgh þat both their natures comen from singulier membris but nat from the substaunce of singulier membris but from þat membre that is next in myght

msItem.title: Tract on the causes of life
msItem.incipit: 2:140r The philosophre puttith .ij. causes of long lif The first whan that ther is in any thyng beyng that the .ij. actief vertues han power vpon the passief and the secunde he puttith anon after that ther be a natural proporcioun bitwix the .ij. actief vertues together and bitwixt the .ij. passief vertues together in the beynges in whiche the myxtioun of the fuyre and water han power vpon the myxtioun of the erth and aier and al suche bien of long substaunce that is to say of long lif
msItem.note: Full transription.

msItem.title: Tractatus de septem planetis et de duodecim signis (English translation)
msItem.incipit: 2:140r-2:140v O glorious god and high creator of al thynges made in the begynnyng of the world .vij. planetis the names of whom bien thiese Saturnus . Jupiter . Mars . Sol . Venus . Mercurius . Luna
msItem.explicit: 2:141v Of planetis sum bien goode and sum bien evil and sum betwixt both . Jupiter and Venus bien goode and thei noyen non of their complexioun ne nonother but defende they from al harme Saturne and Mars bien evil they noyen non of complexioun but alwey corositen . Sol . Mercurius . and Luna bien bitwixt both for they bien goode with goode and evil with evil to theym that bien of þer compexioun they don moche moche goode etcaetera
msItem.note: The title The dispocission of Planettes has been added by a later hand to the outer margin of f. 2:140r.
This text was first identified as a (unique) translation of the Tractatus de septem planetis et de duodecim signis by Mooney (1995), p. 58.

msItem.title: On the Twelve Signs of the Zodiac (possibly a translation of Pseudo-Aristotle/Pseudo-Ptolemy, Liber iudicorum)
msItem.incipit: 2:140v Off signes sum bien masculyne and sum bien femynyne Aries is masculyne and Taurus is femynyne and so thurght the .xij. signes
msItem.explicit: 2:142v The .xij. signe is Pissis a comune signe cold and moist of complexioun . than is it goode to bei and to selle to saile bi the see or oþer watres to sende messangiers to bielde to sette trees to take medicyne and to treate of pees and concorde . be ware thow mete with non enemyes ne touche nat thyn anclees ne thi feete with non egge toole
msItem.finalRubric: 2:142v Thus endith the qualitees or the complexiouns of the .xij. signes - Amen
msItem.note: The title xij. signes has been written in the outer margin of f. 2:140v.

msItem.title: The Book of Life and Death
msItem.author: Pseudo-Hippocrates (here attributed)
msItem.rubric: 2:143r This is the booke of Ipocras in this book he techith to knowe the planete . Sikenes . lif . and deth and the tymes therof
msItem.incipit: 2:143r ffirst saith Ipocras that a leche shal take kepe of the mone wher he is at the ful than wexith bloode and marow brayne and other humores the whiche folown the cours of the mone
msItem.explicit: 2:145r If ther be a sore þat is gray . white or blac . if it be hard he is engendred of coldnenes and drynes . his signes bien . Taurus . Virgo . and Capricornus . his planete is Saturne . and if it be of this colour aforsaide that is to say . gray white or blac and nessh in feelyng it is the kynde of ffleame engendred of cold and moistnes . his signes bien Cancer Scorpio and Pisces his planetis bien eVnus and Luna . This rule is general of al maner surgery of postemes outward
msItem.finalRubric: 2:145r Here endith the Booke of Ipocars of Lif and deth translated of Astronomers the best vpon Avicen
msItem.note: The title Seknesse life and dethe was written by a later hand in the upper margin of f. 2:143r.

msItem.title: Table with notes on the Signs of the Zodiac in relation to humors, planets, and cardinal directions
msItem.incipit: 2:145r Attractief / Colre - Aries / Leo / Sagittarius - bien signes hote and dry and bien of the nature .Sol. and Mars Oriental - Est / fuyre
msItem.explicit: 2:145v Expulsief / ffleomatic - Cancer / Scorpio / Pissis / - bien signe cold and moiste and bien ofthe nature of the mone meanely mercury septemtrional or Borial - North / Water
msItem.note: The title (or subheadings) Digestvy signes - iiij Compleciouns has been added by a later hand to the outer margin of f. 2:145r.

msItem.title: Astrological treatise on the influences of the planets and Signs of the Zodiac upon mankind
msItem.incipit: 2:145v Be the ordynaunce of god that al thyng hath made after his wil hath yeven to aungels his spirites vnderstondyng and konnyng for to moeve the planetis in the .xij. signes wiþ grete cure and busynes of shapyng of man in his moder wombe and hem he hath bitaken it vnto the worldis en
msItem.explicit: 2:153r The .viij. is whan she is in an evil house the whiche bien thiese the .iiij. the .vj. the .vij. the .viij. and the .xij.
msItem.note: The treatise contains fifteen sections. As Mooney (1995) points out, section 3-14 appear elsewhere as a separate work known as the Treatise on the Elections of Times. For the latter work, see Matheson and Shannon (1995).

listBibl.bibl: Matheson and Shannon (1994), pp. 24-29 [edition from another manuscript]

msItem.title: De epidemia (English translation)
msItem.author: John of Burgundy
msItem.incipit: 2:153v Bi cause that al thynges here in erth as wel þe elementis as thynges spryngen and compowned of the elementis bien graunted and ladde bi the bodies than bien in the spieris or cerclis of the firmament as moises hallai syen in their bookes of interpretaciouns
msItem.explicit: 2:156r-2:156v Wherfor bi suche maner accidentis that bien distrucciouns and signes to the phisicion may be wist in what place that avoided or fastned matier lurkith and bi whiche veyne may be avoided and draw oute forwhi if that infect and empoisonned bloode be sent or brought to the arm holis it is wele wist therby that the herte peyned or grevid wherfor
msItem.note: Incomplete copy of the English Long Version of John of Burgundy's De epidemia with Astrological Prologue.

msItem.title: Medicine Against the Pestilence Evil
msItem.author: John of Bordeaux [Barba]
msItem.incipit: 2:156v Here bigynneth a noble treatice made of a goode phisicien John of Burdews for medicyne agenst the pestilence evil and it is departed in .iiij. parties or chapiters
msItem.explicit: 2:158r And thurgh the grace of god he shal escape and be delivered from this sikenes
msItem.finalRubric: 2:158r Here endith the treatice of John de Barba and John of Burdeux made agenst the sikenes pestilencial whiche is þe epedymal anno domini millessimo CCCmo nonogesimo

msItem.title: On eight types of medicines
msItem.incipit: 2:158r Ther bien .viij. maners of medicynes mynistred to the parties of the body withoutfurth whiche bien cald in this maner that is to say Encatisme . Synapisme . Epithyme . Cathaplasme . Fomentacioun . Subfumygacioun and Sacellacioun
msItem.explicit: 2:159r Medicynes bi the [?] aes bien received or taken in .ij. maners for whi it is entremeted in dure substaunce and so it is suppositorye or in liquite and so it is clisterie
msItem.note: The title Medicyns ffor pestlence was added by a later hand to the outer margin of f. 2:158r.

msItem.title: Treatise on the diagnosis and treatment of disease (exerpt from the Liber Uricrisiarum)
msItem.author: Henry Daniel
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with Latin title and quotations
msItem.rubric: 2:159r Prologus istius tractatus secundum linguam maternam
msItem.incipit: 2:159r As salamon saith in his first booke of proverbis the first chapitre that saith thus inicium sapiencie est timor domini begynnyng of wisdom is to drede god and as aristotle saith saith in the thride chapitre of ethikes where he saith thus omnium expediendorum principum est de sapiencia
msItem.explicit: 2:173d verso this vryn betokeneth the same but the infirmyte is not so feruent medicina take figus licoris isop horehownd helena campana and boyle hem in a galon water to the half and vse it
msItem.note: On ff. 2:173a verso-2:173d verso, the treatise features drawings of 20 urine flasks (jordans) decorated with gold and colours. Their accompanying instructions are written by a different hand, but the illustrations clearly belong to the treatise as they are introduced by the main hand on f. 2:172v: Whan thow hast considered al this tofore declared I shal shewe the vrynes and the colours bi picture as hereafter folowith.

This is an abbreviated redaction of the medical compendium that was translated by the cleric 'Austin' for Thomas Plouden (d. 1413), a London citizen and barber-surgeon of the parish of All Hallows the Great, and that can be found almost complete in Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 176/97 [see Voigts (1989)), p. 382; Mooney (1995), p. 60; Tavormina (2014), p. 96 (no. 17.0)].

This treatise contains several embedded uroscopic items: ff. 2:170r-2:170v contain the first half of chapter 1 of an abridged version of Henry Daniel's Liber Uricrisiarum [see Tavormina (2014), p. 91 (no. 15.3)]; ff. 2:170v-2:172v contain a list of the Twenty Colours of Urine [see Tavormina (2014), p. 47 (no. 6.2c)]; ff. 2:172v-2:173r contain an abbreviated version of the Cleansing of Blood [see Tavormina (2014), p. 34 (no. 3.3.2a)]; ff. 2:173r-2:173v contain the Practica Urinarum [see Tavormina (2014), p. 75 (no. 11.2)]; and ff. 2:173a verso-2:173d verso contain The Twenty-Jordan Series (Rufus incipit), [see Tavormina (2005), no. 38; Tavormina (2014), p. 19 (no. 1.3)].

msItem.title: Medical recipe for sciatica
msItem.note: Added after the main text of the preceding treatise on the diagnosis and treatment of disease and before its illustrations of urine flasks.

msItem.title: Treatise on pestilence (with appended Six-Token List)
msItem.rubric: 2:174r And folowyng here next bigynneth an approbate treatise for the pestilence studied bi the grettest doctours of phisik amonges the vniuersites of cristendom and amonges al cristen naciouns in the tyme of seynt Thomas of Caunterbury
msItem.incipit: 2:174r For the vniuersal goode of al cristen people to lierne the most soverayne medicyne of diete of bloode leetyng and of herbis and moche other counsails of solempne doctours for the epydemye cleped the pestilence whan the people bien enfact of that sikenes loke for sure and notable doctryne . men to ferbere the etyng of leekis of garlik of oynons and al other metis that bien hote of nature
msItem.explicit: 2:175v Bi thiese ensamples ye may have notice of your estatis Ther bien also the daies of the yeare that bien most perilous and sikeliest any man for to leete hym bloode vpon bi writyng and doctryne of seynt Bede and thiese creatures of man that letith hym bloode vpon any of thiese .iij. daies he shal
msItem.note: The Six-Token List occurs on ff. 2:175r-2:175v [see Tavormina (2007), pp. 634, 636, 647, 651-65; Tavormina (2014), p. 37 (no. 4.1.3c)]. The text ends imperfectly.

listBibl.bibl: Tavormina (2007), pp. 634, 636, 647, 651-65 [edition of Six-Token List on ff. 2:175r-2:175]

msItem.title: Alphabetical glossary with equivalents for names of herbs, spices, gums and trees
msItem.rubric: 2:175v Here bigynnen the synonymes and even voices of dyuers spices herbis gummes and of trees literaly bi lettres of the A B C
msItem.incipit: 2:175v Arthemisia mater herbarum moder of herbes matricaria vel martha in inglissh mugwort hote and moist in .iij.o gradu
msItem.explicit: 2:201r Zipule id est crispelle
msItem.finalRubric: 2:201r Here enden the synonymes and even voices of dyuers spices herbis gummes and tres litteraly bi the lettres of the A B C

msItem.title: List of names of herbs and spices [Tabula aromaticorum]
msItem.textLang: Latin text with Middle English rubrics
msItem.rubric: 2:201r Here bigynneth the first table of maiste valerne of whos first piller table is of emagogis and so he bigynneth
msItem.incipit: 2:201v Diantos / Manna / Cassia fistula
msItem.explicit: 2:212r Q[ui]tbibici / Oliua / Castoreum
msItem.note: The title Names of Yerbis and Spicis has been written by a later hand to the outer margin of f. 2:201r.

msItem.title: Names and definitions of diseases
msItem.incipit: 2:212r Asma is an evil in the brest as it were a maner cowgh
msItem.explicit: 2:213v Blak Jaundice - Ictoricia that is the blac jawnys and it cometh of a malencoly and in sum bookes of phisique it is cleped melanchiron

msItem.title: Diagnosis and treatment of abdominal pain
msItem.incipit: 2:213v Here it techith for to knowe the colica passio thiese bien the signes prikynges gnawynges and akynges and sorow byneth þe navil and braking above of thiese dyuers encheasouns that is to wite fulnesse and swellyng with a ventosite that is wynd of glaymyssh flewme gadered with hardenes and drought
msItem.explicit: 2:213v and do hem vse with diacalamente and diacumin [sic: diacuminum] the grete trific and diatesseron and diaspermaton and the grete triacle and lete hem be ventused withoute fuyre
msItem.note: The title Collica passio has been added by a later hand to the outer margin of f. 2:213v.

msItem.title: Collection of eight medical recipes
msItem.note: The last recipe is an instruction for making a Cered Clothe ffor a Brossure.

msItem.title: Treatise on making and using scientific instruments (celestial sphere, astrolabe, new and old quadrant, gauging rod, and staff of Jacob) (excerpts from the Treatise on the Astrolabe)
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 2:215r Whan ye wil compowne or make this instrument bi the grace of god without whos help may nothyng be fynaly triewe and parfite ffirst ye shuln make a rounde bal of metal or ellis of solide and holl tymber the whiche is the better after myn estymacioun the maner roundyng of this bal is this Take a pece of solide tymber and hewe it as rounde as ye may with an axe til it be of a sperik fourme Than fynde out .ij. opposit pointis in it in the most subtiliest wise that ye may or can with a compas
msItem.explicit: 2:238v And of this maner of reason is forwhi vessel roddis or of gawgyng yerdis to what maner it is made to mesure boþ rounde vessels and in compas But forwhi the quadrate or .iiij. square without compas bihavith hym silf as is .xiiij. to .xj. Therfor to the first invencioun owght to be multiplied bi .xiiij. and the product therof divide bi .x. and it shal shewe
msItem.note: The treatise contains excerpts from Geoffrey Chaucer's Treatise on the Astrolabe on ff. 2:231v-2:234r.
Blank spaces throughout the treatise indicate that drawings of the described scientific instruments were originally planned but never executed.
The title or subheading Makyng of a speer etcaetera was added by a later hand to the outer margin of f. 2:215r.

The treatise's chapters end with reference to a certain Multon: Quod Multon occurs on ff. 2:215r [with the date 1458], 2:217r, 2:219r, 2:222r. The signatures may refer to the London stationer John Multon (d. 1475). The latter may be the 'Hammond Scribe' [see Origin] but Mooney (1995) thinks this unlikely since his name only occurs in this text and not in any other texts in this or other manuscripts copied by the Hammond Scribe. Instead, Mooney suggests that Multon was the source of this work.

msItem.title: Testimony regarding the efficacy of medicines in this volume
msItem.incipit: 2:234r this boke of medycynes is provid and tryede to be true you may be well assuryde that euery kynde of medycyne ys wounderfull good for the desease hit speaketh of as any be in all the worelde
msItem.note: Full transcription as in Mooney (1995). Added by a late 15th- or 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Opening of a hymn based on (?) Psalm 23
msItem.incipit: 2:236r (upper margin) The Lord is only my support / And he which doth me keep
msItem.note: Added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Treatise on the dispositions of the planets, on those of men born in each of the months or under each of the signs of the Zodiac, and of the influences of the planets upon mankind
msItem.rubric: 2:239r Of the .vij planetis
msItem.incipit: 2:239r As ther bien .vij. planetis Saturnus of al is hier in his cercle and he is the signifior and tokener of auncient riche men and riches and religions and erthtiliers or ploughmen and of auncient and old men whiche as he is impedyment or letter in houre and tyme of reuolucioun a distroier of whatsumever is in his domynacioun
msItem.explicit: 2:244v ffor soth if he be bore vnder a malinolous constellacioun from that evil that it is of kynde declyne he everlastyng and drawe he in to a goode chaunge . that if he so do worthy rewardes of good god he shal take . that is to say everlastyng lif

msItem.title: Treatise of the Seven Liberal Arts
msItem.incipit: 2:244v Glorious and mervailaus god in al his werkis the verray craft of wisdam of the fader of hevene . whiche in the bigynnyng beyng bifore al creatures . as witnessith scripture made al creatures of nought and man after the image and symilitude of the holi trynite puttyng hym in so high and grete dignite . indowed hym with so grete giftes both in boyd and in soule
msItem.explicit: 2:254r for the whiche the .vij. special sciences bien necessarie and principaly ordeyned . AS it was saide in the bigynnyng of this writyng . thurgh the wisdam of the fader of hevene who be blessid withouten end Amen

msItem.title: Three problems in geometry
msItem.incipit: 2:254r A rewele to make a square of a rounde cercle as thus ffirst make youre cercle and drawe a square from side to side of the cercle than drawe a crosse from corner to corner and divide the space from the brymme of the cercle to the corner of the swuare in .x. partis equal and .vj. partis of the .x. partis from the cercle And in like wise at the corners and drawe from .vj. to vj. and take there a parfit square of a cercle as thus an example
msItem.explicit: 2:254v than divide the .iiij. part of þe cercle aboute bi the same .x. and the quocient wil shewe .viij. the whiche is .x. tymes .viij. and that makith .lxxx. and on that day shal the hed of the tree rest on the [a]n the grounde as thus an example
msItem.note: The treatise features additional notes and drawings by John Fortho who gives his name in his first annotation in which he comments on the example described in the text: The example wantinge: I thought good to adde it Joh: Fortho. Two of Fortho's geometrical drawings have been added in the outer margin of f. 2:254r (one drawn on the page and the other on a paper pastedown). He added a third larger pastedown with a diagram that shows The arche ye tree toppe makes in his fall on a blank space below the text on f. 254v. He signs his note below the diagram with his name: John Fortho. Subsequently, he adds notes with the heading: So Friar Baon explained. These notes spill over onto the lower margin of the next page, f. 2:255r.

msItem.title: Table for determining the hour of the day using the shadow of a vertical object
msItem.rubric: 2:255r Hec tabula docet inuenire horam diei per vmbram alicuius rei perpendiculariter erecte in .6. partes diuise equales omni die et hora per annum
msItem.note: The table consists of columns with the names of the month written above them and rows with numbers indicating the days of the months.

msItem.title: Two Guidonian hands with music notation
msItem.incipit: 2:256a recto G ut / A re / B my
msItem.explicit: 2:256a recto B fa / [B durum] my / A la mi re / G sol re ut / F fa ut
msItem.finalRubric: 2:256a recto Ter .G. [B durum] quarre bis .C. properchant .F. duo .B. mol
msItem.note: A full-page drawing of two palms of the left hand. On the left, a hand shows how musical notes correspond to solfège syllables; and, on the right, a hand shows how the notes on the hand on the left correspond with music notation (neumes). Below the hand is a banderol with a verse that may have been derived from Guido of Arezzo's Micrologusare. Below are two four-lines staves with neumes in red and black ink.

msItem.title: Table on superparticular intervals
msItem.rubric: 2:256a verso Proporciones super particulares
msItem.incipit: 2:256a verso Sesque altera .2.3.4.6.9.8.12.
msItem.explicit: 2:256a verso Multiplices superparcientes et sic de singulis: Dupla superbiparciens .3.8.9.28.64 / Dupla supertriparciens .4.11.16.14.112.
msItem.note: The text is presented in a triangular table.

msItem.title: Musical table
msItem.rubric: 2:256b recto Cribrum proporcionum
msItem.incipit: 2:256b recto pla. 10. tu
msItem.explicit: 2:256b recto sesque nocu pla
msItem.note: A triangular table.

msItem.title: Table showing the different neumes (square notation) and their values
msItem.incipit: 2:256b verso Larga . Duplicum . Simplicium . Breuium . Semi Brevium . Minorum . Pause . Longarum . Longa
msItem.note: A triangular table showing the different neumes and their duration.

msItem.title: Canons to accompany a perpetual kalendar or almanack (which is lacking), translated from Arabit into Latin in 1307 or 1347
msItem.incipit: 2:257r Almanak translated in perpetuite out of arabike into latin the yeere of our lord .Ml CCCvij. whiche parfitely . withdrawen . Ml CCCvj. vnder of the yeeris of our lord and that remayneth cal the residue in the name of our lord Jhesu Crist bigynnyth the Almanak in perpetuite to be founde the veray placis of planetis in signis . withdrawe from the yeere of our lord .Ml CCCvj. and with the residue entre in to the table of planetis of everiche that is to say . in to the yeere . moneth andday and thow shalt fynde his veray place if god wil
msItem.explicit: 2:258v-2:259r And if ther be bitwene hem . Clxxx. neither more nor lasse [crossed out: if] he hath no latitude . and if ther be bitwene hem more . than . Clxxx and lasse than . CClxxviij. and lasse than CCClx. it is meridional ascendyng and than with that ther be CCClx. grees bitwene hem and no lasse the moone hath no latitude
msItem.finalRubric: 2:259r Here endith Alamanak from Arabic into latyn translated the yeere of our lord god
msItem.note: As Mooney (1995) notes, the introduction gives 1307 for the Almanak's translation (three times) but the final rubric gives 1347.

msItem.title: Declarationes abbatis sancti Albani super kalendarium Regine (English translation)
msItem.author: Richard of Wallingford
msItem.incipit: 2:259r If questioun be made of the nativite of man and the planetis bien in grees males this shal be to them strong and if the questioun be of the nativite of womman and the planetis bien in grees femynyne this shal be to hem a stranger gree Azamana that is a gree of a fieble body so expowned fforsoth Azamana is such a fieblenes of body as def blynd losse of membres and like thynges whiche a man hath in this lif
msItem.explicit: 2:260v And in contrarie in the natiuite of wymmen Planetis beyng in femynyn degrees signes and qartis maken hem shaply apparible of laudabil deedis and bi grete of name [sic] ffosoth in grees masculyne signes and qartis planetis beyng in there natiuitees maken hem abhomynable in their deedis and sayenges
msItem.note: The titles Nativite of man and Planetes have been added by two early annotaters in the outer margin of f. 2:259r.

msItem.title: Prognostications on thunder occuring in each sign of the Zodiac
msItem.incipit: 2:260v In whatsumever signe it thundrith outher in the day or in the nyght that bitokenyth the same yeere forsoþ shal be but another thunder come of that in the secunde signe and of þe former thunder knowen shall perissh
msItem.explicit: 2:261r Therfor in thiese chapitres canonized tymes and temperal mutaciouns or chaunges most to be considred
msItem.note: The title Thonder has been added by a later hand to the outer margin of f. 2:260v.

msItem.title: Introductory treatise on astronomy
msItem.incipit: 2:261r Raby moyses the philophre saith in suche a booke that al the body of þe erth is rounde as a tenys ball and evene everywhere and though ther be many hillis and mountaynes in thoo thynges alonly ther is is as many valeys and dennes to the equalitee of it in compensacioun and makyng
msItem.explicit: 2:262r zona or girdel is a part of the hevenely spiere divide in .v. equal parties axis is the right lyne from the lasse mount vnto the more probably vnderstanden etcaetera
msItem.note: The title of þe erth is written in the outer margin of f. 2:261r.

msItem.title: Table of aspects of the moon with the other planets
msItem.rubric: 2:262v Aspectus lune cum ceteris planetis
msItem.note: The table consists of six columns with the following headings: Coniunctio, Sextilis, Quartus, Trinus, Oppositus. The colum has six rows with the following headings: Saturnus, Jubiter, Mars, Sol, Venus, and Mercurius.

msItem.title: Collection of about 30 medical recipes
msItem.note: The first recipe is incomplete due to the loss of f. 2:263. One recipe on f. 2:264r is attributed to a certain Sutton (outer margin). Another recipe, entitled A comfortatief Roiall, on f. 2:265r is attributed to Maister Rogier Necton Doctour, referring to Roger Necton (d. 1484), who studied medicine at the University of Oxford and was a Doctor of Medicine by 1446. He was rector of St Mary Woolnoth, City of London, from 1464 until 1484. On f. 2:266r is a recipe for purging and on f. 2:266v is an electuarie that are both attributed to a certain Magister Mathew.

msItem.title: Three medical recipes
msItem.note: Added by a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: A single medical recipes
msItem.note: Unfinished and fragmentary ([Savenstom] and boiled with war and turputin). Added by a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Three medical recipes
msItem.note: The recipes are headed Pulius Triasandali, Pulius pro pectore, Pulius peregrini. On the reverse of f. 2:[266a] verso is written the single title (vertically): Triasaundala in reference to the first recipe.

msItem.title: Collection of about 35 medical recipes
msItem.note:
The recipes were added in the late 15th or early 16th century. Several of them have been attributed to named medical pracitioners:
a plaster for phlegm and swelling on f. 2:[266a] verso is attributed to a certain Bagshawe [Mooney (1993), p. 1029 fn. 12 suggests that he may have been Robert Bekynsaw, fellow of Michaelhouse in the early 16th century, and president of Queen's College from 1508 to 1519 and chaplain and almoner to Queen Catherine by 1509]
two recipes for treating aches on f. 2:267v are said to have been proved by M Pollen
a recipe to heal a sore on f. 2:267v is said to have been proved by the wif of þe georg
a recipe to cure farcy in a horse on f. 2:268r is attributed to a Henry Shepard
a recipe to treat shakyng aksis on f. 2:268r is attributed to a J yevans
a recipe to treat pain in a woman's back on f. 2:268r is attributed to Clawdius the wif de Cottyngham [Mooney (1993), p. 1029 fn. 12 suggests that this attribution refers to a local medical practitioner in Cottenham, Cambridgeshire]
a water for psalsy ffransy collyk grawyng at ones herton f. 2:268v is attributed to a Magister fflemyng [Mooney (1993), p. 1029 fn. 12 thinks it probable that he is John Flemyng, fellow of Pembroke Hall in 1450-1457, treasurer of Pembroke Hall in 1451-1453, senior proctor of the University in 1453-54. From 1457, Flemyng served the future King Edward Iv and remained in royal service from his accession in 1461 until 1468, first as his clerk and chaplain and after that as his proctor at the Roman curia]
a recipe for a gret ache iche or scate and a gret kelere in manys leg on f. 2:268v is said to have been proved in death by my lord Bornes
a recipe for a medicinal water on f. 2:269v is attributed to Magister fflemyng [see above]
a recipe for to breke ffleme on f. 2:269v is attributed to Henry Sheppard
a recipe for treating awes in annus on f. 2:269v is said to have been per B wif proved
a recipe for treating gout on f. 2:270r is attributed to Dauid Rekamtsal [Recampstall]
a recipe on f. 2:270v is said to have been used by magister Morys to heal the leg of Richard Merwyn
a recipe for Morffew on f. 2:272r is attributed to Magister Arthur Darcy

msItem.title: Instruction for making the ointment of Mary Magdalene
msItem.rubric: 2:267r Mary
msItem.incipit: 2:267r Take the oyl of \Mary/ maudleyn and herbame that som men calle Oil of Spike and som Oil of Marcill the whiche ys to many and diuerse pascions that be cureable [Crossed out: Why ys called Balsam of Mary Magdeleyn for she proued the same balsam vpon our lord Jhesu cryst and anoynted his body therwith this oyl ys not sond but ther as þe sepulcre [? ybrost] mary magdelen]
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the late 15th- or 16th century. The scribe appears to have left the legend about the balm of Mary Magdalene unfinished and potentially crossed the written text out.

msItem.title: Tract on the virtues of the Balsam of Mary Magdalene
msItem.rubric: 2:267r Thes ben þe vertuse þerof with [? ine/mo]
msItem.incipit: 2:267r hit preserueth a man from pestelence for yf a man anoynt his handys oþer smelle þerto or to put a drop into his nose the sauer þerof fille þe veynes and membres of mans body so þat þat þer may no evill eyre enter nor venemus in to his body
msItem.explicit: 2:267r Item where þis oyll pe sett it wol distroy mowthis
msItem.note: Added in the late 15th- or 16th century.

msItem.title: Dates of Easter for the years 1519-1529
msItem.rubric: 2:269r Almenac pro xijs annis
msItem.note: List for the years 1519-1529 providing the dates of Easter for these years, their Golden Numbers and Dominical Letters; added in the early 16th century.

msItem.title: Date of Easter for the year 1573
msItem.incipit: 2:269r M.l V.C.lxxiij: ester day was the .xxij. day of marche . and our lady day was on the wesday in the ester wyke - Henri Dyneley
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by the hand of Henry Dyngley (b. c. 1515-d. 1589) of Charlton, Cropthorne, Worcestershire, probably after 1573.

msItem.title: Note on the beginning of the Dog Days
msItem.rubric: 2:269r vjto die Julli hic Incipiunt dies Caniculares
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by in the early 16th century.

msItem.title: Note on dates of Dog Days
msItem.incipit: 2:269r Canyclere dayes begynythe þe xxiiij day of jull and endethe þe vth day of september next after
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the late 15th- or 16th century.

msItem.title: Tract on waters and their properties
msItem.rubric: 2:270r Waters and þer propertes
msItem.incipit: 2:270r Water of egremond is good for sore woundes and hit dothe away yewkyng
msItem.explicit: 2:270r Water of violetes is god to [b]ele a man þat is thyrsty ffor þe raynes for þe lyuer þe jawndyse and vnkynd het in þe stomak
msItem.note: Added in the late 15th- or 16th century.

msItem.title: On apothecary weights and measures
msItem.incipit: 2:270v ℈ est pondus
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for the colic
msItem.rubric: 2:270v a gleyster for the Colyke
msItem.note: The recipe is signed by Thomas Sandy (Thomas S) who seems to have copied it into this manuscript. The same hand also copied a plague recipe on f. 2:272r.

msItem.title: Recipe for the pestilence
msItem.author: King Henry VIII (attributed)
msItem.rubric: 2:272rKyng Henry þe vijth medicien for the pestilens probatum este
msItem.note: The recipe is signed by Thomas Sandy (Per Thomas Sandy) who seems to have copied it into this manuscript. He also copied a recipe for a gleyster for the Colyke on f. 2:270v.

Similar or identical recipes attributed to a King can be found in other manuscirpts, including: Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Ashmole 1444: A medisone for the plage which the Kinges grace sent my lord Mayer of London; Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Ashmole 1447: The Kinges medicine to defend from the pestilence; Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Rawlinson C 816: A soverayne good medycyne for the plague or pestilence whyche Kynge Henry the VIIth used; and San Marino, Huntington Library, HM 144: medesyn that the kyngis grace vsythe every day for the raynyng seknys.

msItem.title: Charm for curing animals
msItem.rubric: 2:272r for madnes in a best
msItem.incipit: 2:272r + Aro Boro Bas Riro Riras
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the late 15th- or 16th century. Mooney (1995) misidentifies this text as a heraldic motto and transcribes the final words as a person's name: Riro [Ricardo?] Roos.

msItem.title: Saying or motto
msItem.incipit: 2:272v ffelix quem faciunt aliena pericula cautum - quod G R
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the late 15th- or 16th century.

msItem.title: Saying
msItem.incipit: 2:272v Quid quid agis prudenter agis et respice ffinem
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the late 15th- or 16th century.

supportDesc.support:
Parchment (f. [i] and f. 2:271) and paper (ff. 1:1r-2:270, folded in folio. Four types of watermarks on the manuscript's original leaves: Hand Letter P Crown and Scissors.
Added leaf f. 2:256: Mountain.
Added leaves f. 2:173b and f. 2:173d: Church.
For a detailed discussion of the manuscript's watermarks, see Pahta (2006), p. 2 fn. 4.

foliation.p: 15th-century foliation in Arabic numerals; supplemented by modern foliation
foliation.note: Arabic numerals in brown ink in the upper right-hand corners of the rectos of ff. 1:2, 1:3, and 1:4; with foliation added in pencil by a modern foliator to leaves 1:1 and 1:5.
Folios [a] and [c] are blank paper flyleave; f. [b] is a cut leaf; and f. [d] is a torn leaf.

foliation.p: 15th-century foliation by the 'Hammond Scribe' [see Origin] in Roman numerals supplemented by modern foliation:

note.p: Folio 2:[266a] is a smaller paper leaf (170 x 145 mm) that has been sewn with white thread to the verso of f. 2:266 at their lower ends.

This catalogue record follows this foliation and ignores older folio references that have been added to the supplemented leaves by later hands: the Arabic numeral 173 (? 17th century) to f. 2:173a; and CClvij-CClvj (? late 15th/early 16th century) to ff. 2:256a-2:256b.

Folio [e] is a torn paper flyleaf; f. [f] a leaf from a printed book; f. [g] is a stub from the preceding leaf; f. [h] is a blank paper flyleaf. A blank paper stub between [g] and [h] has not been digitised.
For reference purposes in this electronic catalogue record, and in correspondence with scholarship on this manuscript, all Roman numerals have been converted to Arabic numerals.
In order to distinguish between overlapping numbering, the two foliation sequences are prefaced in this record by '1:' and '2:'.

list.item: Quire 1612+4 (ff. 2:167-2:178: 2 bifolia added between the 7th and 8th leaves)
Quire 2312+2 (ff. 2:251-2:262: 1 bifolium added between the 6th and 7th leaves)

formula.p: 1five 2-712 810 9-1512 1612+4 (2 bifolia added between 7th and 8th) 17-2212 2312+2 (1 bifolium added between 6th and 7th) 248-1 (1st missing)

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in brown ink at the centres of the lower margins of the last versos of quires (except for Quires 1, 10, 13, 19, 21, 23, and 24).

layout.seg: Ruled in brown and purple ink, frame and line ruling. Mainly single columns (except ff. 2:201v-2:222r which have two columns). 35-40 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: The original manuscript has been copied by a single scribe, the so-called 'Hammond Scribe' (see Origin), in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.

The 'Hammond Scribe' used a display script for titles and introductions (e.g. 2:1r), opening words of texts (e.g. f. 2:3r), and Latin quotations (e.g. f. 2:5v), comprising a large module textualis script.
Folios 2:52r-2:52v are copied by a 16th-century hand in a cursive script with predominantly secretary features.

Folios 1:1r-1:1v, 2:50r-2:52r, 2:103r-2:106v, 2:135r-2:138v, 2:214r-2:214v, [2:265a] verso-[2:271] recto contain additional texts (mostly medical recipes) by late 15th- or early 16th-century hands writing in cursive scripts with both anglicana and secretary features.
Four recipes added to the lower half of f 2:265v were copied by a 16th-century hand in a cursive script with predominantly secretary features.

Two recipes added to the the bottom of f 2:270v and one recipe added to the lower half of f. 2:272r were copied by the 16th-century hand of Thomas Sandy in a script with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: Two Guidonian hands in dark ink with text and music notation in black and red ink on f. 256a recto.
Twenty urine flasks (jordans) drawn in brown ink with different types of urine as highlighted by the use of colours and gold on ff. 273a verso-273d recto.
Decorative banderols in brown ink for the rubricated headings above drawings of twenty urine flasks (jordans) on ff. 273a verso-273d recto.
Large (2-lines) red initials in frameworks of blue penwork decoration with pen-flourishing in the same colour extending into the margins.
Small (1 line) plain initials in red ink.
Titles and sub-headings written in red ink.
Regular initials in brown ink highlighted in yellow throughout.
Paraphs in red ink; but those in the text that accompanies the drawings of twenty urine flasks (jordans) on ff. 2:173a recto-2:173d verso alternate between blue and red ink.

binding.p: Binding height: 290 mm; width: 215 mm; depth: 70 mm.

The binding is accompanied by flyleaves (ff. [f]-[g]) and pastedowns taken from 1 Maccabees as published in The Cambridge Paragraph Bible of the Authorized English Version with the Text Revised by a Collation of Its Early and other Principal Editions, the Use of the Italic Type Made Uniform, the Marginal References Remodelled, and a Critical Introduction Prefixed, ed. by F. H. Scrivener (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1873).

physDesc.accMat: A loose piece of paper is kept with the manuscript (see letter) that is inscribed in pencil (with R.14.52) and contains an undated typed note on the will of John Furthoe of Cambridge, Doctor of Physicke, that was sent to Mr Greg, i.e. Sir Walter Wilson Greg (1875-1959), Librarian at Trinity College Library from 1907 until 1913.

msDesc.history:
1458×c.1485. ?London.
Copied by the so-called 'Hammond Scribe' between 1458 and c. 1485. The anonymous scribe is named after the Chaucer-scholar Eleanor Prescott Hammond (1866–1933) who first identified their hand in five manuscripts (see Hammond (1905) and Hammond (1929)). Subsequently, scholars have identified ten more manuscripts that were copied by the scribe (see Doyle (1959) and Mooney (2006)). Aside from this manuscript, their hand occurs in the following manuscripts:
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.3.21
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.3.11
London, British Library, Add MS 29901
London, British Library, Add MS 34360
London, British Library, Arundel MS 59
London, British Library, Cotton MS Claudius A VIII
London, British Library, Harley MS 78
London, British Library, Harley MS 372
London, British Library, Harley MS 2251
London, British Library, Harley MS 4999
London, British Library, Royal MS 17 D XV
London, Royal College of Physicians, MS 388
Oxford, Bodleian Library, Rawlinson D.913
Worcester, Cathedral Library, MS F.172
As Mooney (2006) notes, the Hammond Scribe appears to have worked as a clerk in the household of Sir Thomas Cook, member of the Drapers' Company and Mayor of London in 1462-63, possibly under the supervision of his secretary John Vale. The latter's initials occur in a blue and red monograms(QJV for Quod John Vale) at the top of f. 2:1r. As Matheson (2006), I: pp. 65-93, argues, the scribe's spellings suggest that they originated from West Essex although they also used spelling forms occuring in sources from the Central Midlands and London. The dating for the scribe's work is based on two works that they copied into this manuscript: 1. A treatise on making and using scientific instruments that refers to a certain Multon (ff. 2:215r, 2:217r, 2:219r, 2:222r) with the date 1458 (f. 2:215r); 2. A medical recipe that is attributed to the physician Roger Necton who died in 1484. Although scholars have suggested that Multon may refer to the Hammond Scribe's name, it is also possible that he was the author or translator of the treatise (see Mooney (2006), I: pp. 55-63).
John Vale (fl. c. 1460-1480) Vale, John, fl. c. 1460-1480, steward and secretary to Sir Thomas Cook, draper and Mayor of London in 1462-3: a monogram with his initials QJV for Quod John Multon at the top of f. 2:1r may indicate his ownership of this manuscript. There is some doubt since, as Mooney (2006) points out, quod usually indicates an author, translator, or scribe. John Vale's monogram also occurs in London, British Library, Harley MS 2251 (f. 175r) and Worcester, Cathedral Library, MS F.172 (f. 169v). He identifies himself in signatures as the scribe of London, British Library, Add MS 48031A.
John Brampton [Bampton] (fl. 1450-1550) Brampton [Bampton], John, fl. 1450-1550: his (erased) ownership inscription in a heraldic coat of arms with a merchant's mark and motto on f. 2:272v: Iste liber constat Johannis B[r]ampton. Gross (1996), pp. 110-111 fn. 68 proposes that he must have been related to the family of fishmongers and wool merchants descended from the alderman William Brampton. A John Brampton held a tenement near Bishopsgate from the Hospital of St Bartholomew and was auditor of the accounts of the Wardens of London Bridget in arrear in 1467. The latter was MP for London in 1472-5, collector of the Petty Custom until 1483, and royal pensioner in 1485-6. Evidence for this identification can be found in Cambridge, Trinity College, O.3.11, another manuscript copied by the Hammond Scribe, which features a copy of a legal document with reference to a John Brampton at ff. 101r-101v.
Janet Forster (fl. late 15th century) Forster, Janet, fl. late 15th century: her name written a late 15th-century hand in the outer margin of f. 2:140v: Jenet fforster. As Pahta (2006) notes, this may refer to the daughter of Sir Thomas Cook, Joan, who married John Forster.
Thomas Sandy [Sandye] (fl. 16th century) Sandy [Sandye], Thomas, fl. 16th century: his name occurs in the lower margin of f. 2:135r: Thomas Sandye; and below two recipes in his hand on f. 2:270v and f. 2:272r. The name Thomas Sandy also occurs in Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Rawlinson B. 173 (ff. 144r, 200r).
Henry Dyngley (1515-1589) Dyngley, Henry, 1515-1589, of Cropthorne, Worcestershire, collector of medieval manuscripts: owned and annotated the manuscript. He added his initials: HD 1573 on f. 2:28r; his name Henry Dyneley on f. 2:269r; the date of easter in the year 1573 to f. 2:269r. For his other notes see Pahta (2006), p. 12. For further details about Dyngley and his collection of manuscripts, see Old Books, New Science as part of the The Making and Knowing Project: Research and Teaching Companion.
William Haekins [Hawkins] (fl. c. 1560-1580) Haekins [Hawkins], William, fl. c. 1560-1580, vicar of Bridge Sollers, Herefordshire (1561-1586): owned or accessed the manuscript; copied a brief sermon about natural monotheism on blank spaces on ff. 2:52r-2:52v.
Margaret Capell (fl. 16th century) Capell, Margaret, fl. 16th century: her name, smudged or partially erased, occurs in a (?) 16th-century inscription on f. 2:139r: per me Margaret Capell [also transcribed as Capett: see Pahta 2006]. She is unidentified but there was, for example, a Margaret Capell (1594-1667) of Little Hadham, Hertfordshire.
M.R. (fl. 1587) M.R., fl. 1587: their name inscribed in the lower margin of f. 2:139r: God sau Elizabeth ouer Noble Queen may the 23th Ano Domini 1587 - MR.
Edward Fortho [Furthoe] (fl. late 16th century)Fortho [Furthoe], Edward, fl. late 16th century: owned or accessed the manuscript. His name inscribed in a note on f. 2:244r (upper margin): Per me Edward Furtho sonn to William Furtho grocer in the old chaindge in londoun at the roase and croune in the old chaindge.
John Fortho [Furthoe] (d. 1633)Fortho [Furthoe], John, d. 1633, M.A., M.D., Fellow and Senior Bursar of Trinity College: owned the manuscript, and added his name (Joh: Fortho) and initials to geometrical drawings and notes he added to f. 2:254r-2:255r (lower margin); also added marginal notes and underlinings to ff. 2:156r, 2:157r-2:157v, 2:173c verso, and 2:242v (and other locations). Bequeathed to Trinity College by John Fortho [Furthoe] (d. 1633), M.A., M.D., Fellow and Senior Bursar of Trinity CollegeFortho [Furthoe], John, d. 1633. In his will of 22 January 1633 (proved on 5 March of that year), Fortho stipulates that the Master and Fellows of Trinity College can select 'twenty of my best books whereof I shalbe possessed of at my death being such as then have not already in their Colledge Library to be delivered to them at their choyce within sixe moneths after my decease. And if they shall make choyce of Fryer Bacons manuscript for one of them, then my will and minde is that if at any time hereafter the trew owner of the same that can make true and lawfull challenge therevnto and proove it his owne, will not be contented or intreated to give the originall manuscript to the said Colledge Library then I desire the said Master and ffellowes at their owne charge to cause the same to be fayrely copied out and the same copy to be and remaine in the said Colledge library' [see Kew, The National Archives, PROB 11/163/269; cited in Pahta (1998), p. 141]. The manuscript is listed as no. 539 in the list of manuscripts in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (1697), I, part 3. The alpha-numerical elements of its current classmark are printed on three labels pasted onto the spine (R.14.52), inscribed in pencil on the inside of the front cover. Its printed ex libris featuring its armorial coat of arms and name (Collegium S.S. et Individuae Trinitatis in Academia Cantabrigiensi) pasted on f. [i] verso. Its modern library stamp on ff. 1:1r, 2:270v, [ii] verso..

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge: A Descriptive Catalogue, 2 (1902); and Linne R. Mooney, Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XI (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1995).

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.
